title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdos Problem #1088: Distinct Distance Subsets**

Let f_d(n) = minimal m such that any m points in R^d contain n points with all pairwise distances distinct.

**Main Conjecture (OPEN):** Is f_d(n) = 2^{o(d)} for fixed n >= 3?

Known: f_2(3) = 7 (Erdos), f_3(3) = 9 (Croft), f_d(3) = d^2/2 + O(d).
mathContext: This is a Ramsey-type problem in discrete geometry: large sets must contain structured subsets.

title: Point Type
content:
**Point d = Fin d -> R**

A point in R^d is represented as a function from Fin d (indices 0 to d-1) to real numbers.

This is equivalent to a d-tuple (x_0, x_1, ..., x_{d-1}).

title: Euclidean Distance
content:
**dist p q = sqrt(sum_i (p_i - q_i)^2)**

The standard Euclidean distance in R^d.

In 2D: sqrt((x1-x2)^2 + (y1-y2)^2)
In 3D: sqrt((x1-x2)^2 + (y1-y2)^2 + (z1-z2)^2)

title: AllDistancesDistinct
content:
**AllDistancesDistinct S:**

A set S has all pairwise distances distinct if no two different pairs of points have the same distance.

Formally: if dist(p1, p2) = dist(q1, q2) and both pairs are distinct, then {p1, p2} = {q1, q2}.

title: ContainsDistinctDistanceSubset
content:
**ContainsDistinctDistanceSubset T n:**

The set T contains a subset of exactly n points with all pairwise distances distinct.

This is the property we want to guarantee when |T| >= f_d(n).

title: The Function f_d(n)
content:
**f(d, n) = minimal m such that...**

Any set of m points in R^d contains n points with all distances distinct.

This is the central object of study - how does f_d(n) grow with d and n?
mathContext: The function is well-defined because we can always achieve this with enough points.

title: Polynomial Upper Bound
content:
**upper_bound_polynomial:**

f_d(n) <= n^{O_d(1)} for fixed dimension d.

This is an 'easy' bound from pigeonhole: with enough points, many pairs have similar distances, forcing distinct distances somewhere.

title: Erdos-Straus Upper Bound
content:
**erdos_straus_upper_bound:**

f_d(n) <= c_n^d for some constant c_n > 1.

This bound is exponential in d but with a base depending only on n. Erdos and Straus proved this in 1975.

The main conjecture asks if c_n can be made arbitrarily close to 1.
mathContext: Exponential in dimension, but the conjecture asks if it's subexponential (c_n -> 1).

title: One-Dimensional Case
content:
**one_dimensional_case:**

f_1(n) ~ n^2

In R^1 (the real line), we need about n^2 points to guarantee n with all distances distinct.

This is related to Problem #530.
mathContext: In 1D, distances are just |x - y|. The quadratic growth comes from avoiding arithmetic progressions.

title: f_2(3) = 7 (Erdos)
content:
**f_2_3 = 7:**

In the plane, 7 points guarantee 3 with all distances distinct.

**Why 6 is not enough:**
A regular hexagon has only 2 distinct distances (edge length and long diagonal).
So no 3 points have all 3 pairwise distances different.
mathContext: The hexagon is the extremal configuration avoiding 3 points with distinct distances.

title: f_3(3) = 9 (Croft)
content:
**f_3_3 = 9:**

In 3D, 9 points guarantee 3 with all distances distinct.

**Why 8 is not enough:**
A cube has only 3 distinct distances:
- Edge length: 1
- Face diagonal: sqrt(2)
- Space diagonal: sqrt(3)

No 3 vertices have all different pairwise distances!
mathContext: Croft proved this in 1962, establishing the exact value for 3D.

title: f_d(3) = d^2/2 + O(d)
content:
**f_d_3_asymptotic:**

For finding 3 points with distinct distances in R^d, the answer is quadratic in dimension.

f_d(3) = d^2/2 + O(d)

This is polynomial (not exponential!) in d for the n = 3 case.
mathContext: The quadratic growth suggests the conjecture might be true for n = 3 (and maybe all n).

title: The Main Conjecture (OPEN)
content:
**ErdosConjecture:**

For fixed n >= 3, f_d(n) = 2^{o(d)} as d -> infinity.

Equivalently: for all epsilon > 0, eventually f_d(n) <= (1 + epsilon)^d.

This asks: does high dimension help so much that the exponential base goes to 1?

**STATUS: OPEN** - This is the main unsolved question.
mathContext: The conjecture interpolates between polynomial (n = 3 case) and exponential (general upper bound).

title: Connection to Problem #530
content:
**problem_530_connection:**

Problem #530 is the 1-dimensional case of this problem.

It asks: how many points on a line guarantee n with all distances distinct?

Answer: f_1(n) ~ n^2.

title: Connection to Problem #503
content:
**problem_503_connection:**

Problem #503 is the n = 3 case of this problem.

It asks: how many points in R^d guarantee 3 with distinct distances?

Answer: f_d(3) = d^2/2 + O(d).

title: Hexagon Construction
content:
**croft_construction_2d:**

The 6-point extremal configuration in R^2 is a regular hexagon.

Distances: only 2 types (edge = 1, long diagonal = 2).

No 3 vertices have all 3 pairwise distances different!

title: Cube Construction
content:
**croft_construction_3d:**

The 8-point extremal configuration in R^3 is a cube.

Distances: 3 types (edge, face diagonal, space diagonal).

Any 3 vertices have at least 2 equal distances!

title: Summary Theorem
content:
**erdos_1088_summary:**

Collects the main results:
1. Problem is OPEN
2. f_2(3) = 7 (Erdos)
3. f_3(3) = 9 (Croft)

The conjecture f_d(n) = 2^{o(d)} remains unresolved.

title: Problem Status
content:
**erdos_1088_status:**

"OPEN - For fixed n >= 3, is f_d(n) = 2^{o(d)}? The conjecture is unresolved."

This summarizes the current state of knowledge.
